name: The Legend of Zelda: Phantom Hourglass
IGN_title: The Legend of Zelda: Phantom Hourglass Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: The Legend of Zelda: Phantom Hourglass Review - GameSpot
IGN_text:
When looking at specific aspects of Nintendo's latest Zelda offering it's easy to write this one off as too different, too kiddy, or too easy.  Nintendo went for a more casual approach this time around, keeping the amount of hardcore dungeon-crawling to a minimum, and shedding the traditional control scheme for a more casual-friendly approach. But with that being said, Phantom Hourglass is still an extremely ambitious, entertaining, and innovative product.  Hardcore Zelda fans will find this to be an easier experience than previous handheld efforts, but when looking at the total package it's easy to see that amidst the "classic vs. touch" arguments and "hardcore vs. casual" debates that will undoubtedly arise, The Legend of Zelda: Phantom Hourglass is truly an amazing product worthy of praise.  The music is impressive, visual style unrivaled on DS at this point, item design truly innovative, and boss work nothing short of genius.  The game will run hardcore gamers just over 15 hours, with side quests adding an additional five or so on top of it, but more than the sheer length of the game is the fact that Nintendo managed to take the entire world inspired by Wind Waker, shrink it down, and deliver the same living-world experience in a pocket adventure, and it's simply fun to sail, interact in the world, and seek out all the little things that round off the experience.  

It comes down to this:  Great games are made up of a series of truly captivating moments.  A Link to the Past had the unveiling of the master sword, Ocarina of Time hooked gamers with the simplicity and entertainment of riding the Hyrule countryside with Epona for the very first time, and Twilight Princess astonished loyal Zelda fans as they witnessed their hero change forms in the midst of the twilight.  The Legend of Zelda: Phantom Hourglass has those moments too, and while it may be more casual than we'd like, it's captivating, entertaining, and a true adventure worthy of the Zelda name.  It's different, but it's still the real deal.
Gamespot_text: Gorgeous visuals. Touch-screen controls work wonderfully. Lots of nifty puzzles to solve. Great boss fights. A few pacing problems make certain sections of the game a bit of a drag. Some experienced players might find the game a touch easy.
Verdict_Sum: The game will run hardcore gamers just over 15 hours, with side quests adding an additional five or so on top of it. The music is impressive, visual style unrivaled on DS at this point, item design truly innovative, and boss work nothing short of genius. A few pacing problems make certain sections of the game a bit of a drag.

name: The Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword
IGN_title: The Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword HD Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: The Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword Review - GameSpot
Game_Rant_title: 'The Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword' Review - Game Rant
IGN_text: Skyward Sword remains as charming as ever, even if it’s also still dominated by clunky controls and odd gimmicks that are exactly as weird as you remember them. The characters and story have aged like fine wine, the quality of life improvements help alleviate some of the Wii-era wonkiness, and the improved graphics and performance make this version look and play better than ever. Unsolved control issues aside, this airborne adventure is everything you might expect it to be, for better or worse, and playing through it again had me grinning ear-to-ear the whole way through.
Gamespot_text: Excellent dungeon design. A host of worthwhile collectibles. Great boss fights. Strong visuals. Troublesome controls. Lots of padding. Predictable formula.
Verdict_Sum: The characters and story have aged like fine wine. Improved graphics and performance make this version look and play better than ever. Troublesome controls. Lots of padding. Predictable formula.

name: The Legend of Zelda: Spirit Tracks
IGN_title: The Legend of Zelda: Spirit Tracks Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: The Legend of Zelda: Spirit Tracks Review - GameSpot
IGN_text: When it released two years ago, Phantom Hourglass blew us away with impressive visuals, beautiful music, and a huge world packed with plenty to see and do.  What it was missing, however, was some of the hardcore difficulty and classic dungeon puzzles that longtime Zelda fans have come to expect.  What a difference two years makes.  While Spirit Tracks has some obvious deja vu elements and can drag on from time to time, Nintendo's latest pocket Zelda trumps the first game hands-down, delivering amazing bosses once again, now complemented with impressive dungeons, a truly epic challenge in the Spirit Tower, and a substantially longer adventure overall.  Nintendo fans now have two must-play Zelda offerings on DS, as Spirit Tracks is an adventure not to be missed.  Pick it up. You won't be disappointed.
Gamespot_text: Exciting and well-designed dungeons. Controlling phantoms is fun and adds new depth to the series. Lengthy story with plenty of side quests. Innovative boss fights. Frantic multiplayer. Not too challenging.
Verdict_Sum: Spirit Tracks is an adventure not to be missed. Lengthy story with plenty of side quests. Innovative boss fights. Frantic multiplayer. Not too challenging.

name: The Legend of Zelda: The Minish Cap
Gamespot_title: The Legend of Zelda: The Minish Cap Review - GameSpot
Gamespot_text: Classic Zelda gameplay and flavor will please fans.. Lots of new items and abilities.. Dungeons are full of tricky puzzles and tough enemies.. Great visual style.. A little on the short side if you don't undertake side quests.. Very similar to past games..
Verdict_Sum: Classic Zelda gameplay and flavor will please fans. Dungeons are full of tricky puzzles and tough enemies. A little on the short side if you don't undertake side quests. Very similar to past games.

name: The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker
IGN_title: The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker HD Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker Review - GameSpot
IGN_text: As a returning fan, I couldn’t have asked for much of a better treatment. The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker HD holds up as a marvelous game full of unique and wonderful surprises that remind me why it’s the best of the 3D Zeldas. If you’ve never braved this amazing seafaring adventure, the Wii U version offers the definitive way to experience a story that’s both charming and elegant.
Gamespot_text: N/A. .
Verdict_Sum: The Wii U version offers the definitive way to experience a story that’s both charming and elegant. As a returning fan, I couldn’t have asked for much of a better treatment.

name: The Legend of Zelda: Tri Force Heroes
IGN_title: The Legend of Zelda: Tri Force Heroes Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: The Legend of Zelda: Tri Force Heroes Review - GameSpot
IGN_text:
The Legend of Zelda: Tri Force Heroes is more than just a fun co-op diversion from the large-scale solo adventures this series is known for. The challenging, intricate puzzles are great chaotic fun in local multiplayer or for a one-time run through in single-player. Limited communication tools make it difficult to play with adventurers online, but everywhere else it’s a success.

Editor's Note: A former IGN employee, Audrey Drake, worked on the localization of this game. Our reviewer, Jose Otero, joined IGN after she departed.
Gamespot_text: Superb music. Some clever puzzles require deep cooperation between human players. Loot system creates rewarding feedback. Dungeons rarely deviate from a repetitive formula. Single player is tedious. Story is poorly written. Many easy puzzles and similar bosses.
Verdict_Sum: The Legend of Zelda: Tri Force Heroes is more than just a fun co-op diversion from the large-scale solo adventures this series is known for. Limited communication tools make it difficult to play with adventurers online, but everywhere else it’s a success.

name: The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess HD
IGN_title: The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess HD Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess HD Review - GameSpot
Game_Rant_title: The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess HD Review - Game Rant
IGN_text: The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess HD holds plenty of memorable moments that’ve stood the test of time, and Nintendo’s high-definition update does a lot to modernize its look and feel. This cleaner, fresher presentation is still noticeably and disappointingly flat in some ways, but just past that are some of the best puzzles and dungeons to be found anywhere in the series.
Gamespot_text: Charming, old-fashioned approach to exploration.. Thriving open-world laced with activity.. Characters and places that resonate.. Ingenious dungeon segments.. Breathtaking boss encounters.. New dungeon (via Amiibo) focuses on shallow battles.. Unspectacular audio and visuals.. Wolf Link is a limited novelty.. Bereft of challenge..
Verdict_Sum: Nintendo’s high-definition update does a lot to modernize its look and feel. This cleaner, fresher presentation is still noticeably and disappointingly flat in some ways. But just past that are some of the best puzzles and dungeons to be found anywhere in the series.

name: The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess
IGN_title: The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess Review - GameSpot
Game_Rant_title: The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess HD Review - Game Rant
IGN_text:
The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess is, in my opinion, the greatest Zelda game ever created and one of the best launch titles in the history of launch titles -- second only, perhaps, to the at-the-time ground-breaking Super Mario 64. It is also one of the finest games I have ever played. The experience is made better and not worse on Wii. The Wii remote and nunchuk add accuracy and speed to exploration and combat for a heightened sense of immersion. While the game has just about everything going for it, including improved controls, a long and engrossing quest, brain-teasing dungeons and some beautiful graphics, it's not perfect. The difficulty has been upped over Wind Waker, but I wish it were harder still -- the boss fights are oftentimes too easy, for example. Additionally, while the visuals are generally impressive, some textures remain blurry to the point they are noticeable. And finally, I still question why Nintendo refuses to add either voice work to the side characters (especially since Twilight Princess features such an improved, dark storyline) or orchestrated music to the soundtrack.

Nintendo's new console ships with Wii Sports, which effectively demonstrates a new breed of games only possible on Wii. The Zelda franchise is equally exclusive to the machine and Twilight Princess is must-see, must-play and must-own entry into the series that proves over and over again why Nintendo is the best developer in the world.
Gamespot_text: Compelling characters and story. outstanding world and puzzle design. longer than most action adventure games. terrific graphics, from an artistic perspective. Wii-specific elements feel tacked on. graphics and sound sometimes go from nostalgic to dated.
Verdict_Sum: Twilight Princess is one of the best launch titles in the history of launch titles. The Wii remote and nunchuk add accuracy and speed to exploration and combat. While the visuals are generally impressive, some textures remain blurry.

name: The Legend of Zelda
Gamespot_title: The Legend of Zelda Review - GameSpot
Gamespot_text: The first entry in one of gaming's greatest series. Seemingly perfect emulation of the original. Some elements of the game's design haven't aged very well, but that's to be expected.
Verdict_Sum: First entry in one of gaming's greatest series. Seemingly perfect emulation of the original. Some elements of the game's design haven't aged very well.

franchise: The Lord of the Rings The
name: The Lord of the Rings Online

franchise: The Lord of the Rings The
name: The Lord of the Rings War in the North
IGN_title: The Lord of the Rings: War in the North Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: The Lord of the Rings: War in the North Review - GameSpot
Game_Rant_title: 'The Lord of the Rings: War in the North' Review - Game Rant
IGN_text: While it’s admirable that the team had opted to create an original story set alongside the events in the books, you’ll wish that they had attempted to take more risks with the project. The characters are bland and lifeless, and the combat, while fun at first, gets pretty repetitive before too long.
Gamespot_text: A good assortment of Middle-earth environments and characters. Leveling up and acquiring new abilities is rewarding. Fun to collect powerful new weapons and gear. Automated save system leads to infuriating setbacks. Problematic revival mechanic. Frequently odd enemy behavior. Technical issues with multiplayer.
Verdict_Sum: A good assortment of Middle-earth environments and characters. Fun to collect powerful new weapons and gear. Automated save system leads to infuriating setbacks.

franchise: The Lord of the Rings The
name: The Lord of the Rings: Aragorn's Quest
IGN_title: The Lord of the Rings: Aragorn's Quest Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: The Lord of the Rings: Aragorn's Quest Review - GameSpot
IGN_text: Lord of the Rings: Aragorn's Quest is fun and satisfying, if just a tad repetitive action adventure with good fan service to those of you that love the Tolkein novels and Peter Jackson films. Both the Wii and PlayStation 3 version of Aragorn's Quest are virtually identical, but it's pretty clear that the game was originally developed for Wii and quickly converted to PlayStation 3 with rushed Move support. The Wii version easily gets the nod as the one to get.
Gamespot_text: Charming storytelling device. Locations do a terrific job of evoking the films. New abilities and equipment create a constant sense of growth. Accessible to younger players. Motion-control combat is imprecise and lacks challenge. Some visual weirdness.
Verdict_Sum: Charming storytelling device. Locations do a terrific job of evoking the films. New abilities and equipment create a constant sense of growth. Motion-control combat is imprecise and lacks challenge.

franchise: The Lord of the Rings The
name: The Lord of the Rings: Conquest
IGN_title: The Lord of the Rings: Conquest Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: The Lord of the Rings: Conquest Review - GameSpot
IGN_text:
The Lord of the Rings: Conquest is a straightforward affair with very little that will pleasantly surprise anyone who played Star Wars: Battlefront. Its combat and general mission structure is by-the-books and the lack of expandability and feeling of redundancy are felt instantly. Withstanding all of that, Conquest still somehow manages to earn merit on its expert use of The Lord of the Rings license. The environments feel like they're straight from the silver screen and Howard Shore's multiple orchestral pieces are great to fight alongside.

Diehard fans of both online, class-based games and The Lord of the Rings might want to invest the sixty bucks, but if redundant and unimaginative gameplay are things you despise, you'll want to steer clear.
Gamespot_text: Fight epic battles in iconic locations. Evil campaign is morbidly delightful. Cutscenes and music create dramatic atmosphere. Playing as trolls, ents, and heroes is exciting. Battles often boil down to button mashing. Many cheap ways to die. Playing campaign solo can be aggravatingly hard.
Verdict_Sum: Fight epic battles in iconic locations. Cutscenes and music create dramatic atmosphere. Battles often boil down to button mashing. Many cheap ways to die. Playing campaign solo can be aggravatingly hard.

franchise: The Lord of the Rings The
name: The Lord of the Rings: The Battle for Middle-Earth II
IGN_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Battle for Middle-earth II Review
Gamespot_title: The Lord of the Rings, The Battle for Middle-earth II Review
IGN_text:
Battle for Middle-earth II is proof that EA was serious about getting back into the good graces of serious RTS fans. There's a lot to experience with this entry into the series including three new factions, a redesigned base building mode, some awesome new powers, terrific improvements to the engine, a tighter campaign mode, and both skirmish and War of the Ring. This might actually be a detriment to some players who liked the simplicity of the first game, but I'm quite pleased. It's a pretty traditional RTS, but it's also a very good one.

What makes me happier is that there's very little for me to say that's particularly bad aside from some gripes with War of the Ring mode and some occasional issues with multiplayer. EA has created a game on a scale big enough to feel part of Middle-earth and managed to keep the gameplay under control at the same time. There's still room for improvement, but nothing big enough to keep me from endorsing it. This is the Lord of the Rings RTS I was hoping for the first time around.
Gamespot_text: Fast-paced real-time strategy with authentic Tolkien flavor. War of the Ring mode lets you really battle for Middle-earth. Excellent production values, beautiful graphics, great sound. Single-player campaigns are fairly generic. War of the Ring mode suffers from many weird logical gaps.
Verdict_Sum: Battle for Middle-earth II is proof that EA was serious about getting back into the good graces of serious RTS fans. There's a lot to experience with this entry into the series including three new factions, a redesigned base building mode, some awesome new powers, terrific improvements to the engine, a tighter campaign mode, and both skirmish and War of the Ring.

franchise: The Lord of the Rings The
name: The Lord of the Rings: The Battle for Middle-Earth
IGN_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Battle for Middle-earth II Review
Gamespot_title: The Lord of the Rings, The Battle for Middle-earth Review
IGN_text:
Battle for Middle-earth II is proof that EA was serious about getting back into the good graces of serious RTS fans. There's a lot to experience with this entry into the series including three new factions, a redesigned base building mode, some awesome new powers, terrific improvements to the engine, a tighter campaign mode, and both skirmish and War of the Ring. This might actually be a detriment to some players who liked the simplicity of the first game, but I'm quite pleased. It's a pretty traditional RTS, but it's also a very good one.

EA has created a game on a scale big enough to feel part of Middle-earth and managed to keep the gameplay under control at the same time. There's still room for improvement, but nothing big enough to keep me from endorsing it. This is the Lord of the Rings RTS I was hoping for the first time around.
Gamespot_text: Big battles that capture the feel of the movies.. Campaign map lets you decide where to go next.. Excellent graphics and sound effects.. Voices provided by most of the movie cast.. Heroes can get in the way at times.. The battles tend to be long wars of attrition.. AI is easy to manipulate..
Verdict_Sum: Battle for Middle-earth II is proof that EA was serious about getting back into the good graces of serious RTS fans. Three new factions, a redesigned base building mode, some awesome new powers, terrific improvements to the engine, a tighter campaign mode, and both skirmish and War of the Ring.

Gamespot_title: The Lord of the Rings, The Third Age Review - GameSpot
Gamespot_text: Lots of character customization options via stats, abilities, and items. Great voice acting. Skill-up system is necessary but tedious. Slowdown, especially in the PS2 version. Light on character interaction, heavy on wizard speeches.
Verdict_Sum: Great voice acting. Lots of character customization options via stats, abilities, and items. Skill-up system is necessary but tedious. Slowdown, especially in the PS2 version.

name: Tom Clancy's  Ghost Recon Advanced Warfighter (weekly JP sales)
Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Advanced Warfighter
IGN_title: Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Advanced Warfighter 2 Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Advanced Warfighter Review
IGN_text: It's too bad that GRAW 2 fans get what essentially boils down to GRAW-lite.  You aren't in control of friendly forces, nor do you need your drones or a lot of the other weapons.  The level of tension over the story is tuned way down thanks to your regeneration ability and the high level of stupidity that the AI demonstrates.  Multiplayer, if you can call it that, is basic and unimpressive.  While the story material is interesting as a fill in between the original and GRAW 2, the PSP version is one that only hardcore fans will like, and only for the short amount of time it takes them to defeat the game.
Gamespot_text: Campaign is exciting and challenging, even at normal difficulty. The door-gunner missions are awesome. Offers a definite tactical feel with its difficulty. Amazing graphics and presentation. Really looks and feels like you're in a city.... ...except there are no civilians. Teammate artificial intelligence leaves something to be desired. Bright, high-contrast lighting can sometimes make it difficult to see.
Verdict_Sum: Campaign is exciting and challenging, even at normal difficulty. Offers a definite tactical feel with its difficulty. Multiplayer is basic and unimpressive. Bright, high-contrast lighting can sometimes make it difficult to see.

name: Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Advanced Warfighter 2
IGN_title: Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Advanced Warfighter 2 Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Advanced Warfighter 2 Review
IGN_text: It's too bad that GRAW 2 fans get what essentially boils down to GRAW-lite.  You aren't in control of friendly forces, nor do you need your drones or a lot of the other weapons.  The level of tension over the story is tuned way down thanks to your regeneration ability and the high level of stupidity that the AI demonstrates.  Multiplayer, if you can call it that, is basic and unimpressive.  While the story material is interesting as a fill in between the original and GRAW 2, the PSP version is one that only hardcore fans will like, and only for the short amount of time it takes them to defeat the game.
Gamespot_text: Intense, gritty modern infantry combat. Impressive multiplayer suite with countless combinations of competitive and cooperative game modes. Good looking graphics and excellent sound effects. The single-player campaign is over before you know it. Since GRAW2 is the first GRAW game for PS3, you feel like you're missing part of the story.
Verdict_Sum: GRAW 2 fans get what essentially boils down to GRAW-lite. You aren't in control of friendly forces, nor do you need your drones or a lot of the other weapons. The level of tension over the story is tuned way down.

name: Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon 2: Summit Strike
Gamespot_title: Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon 2 Summit Strike Review - GameSpot
Gamespot_text: Varied and interesting campaign. Huge levels. Tons of multiplayer modes, including co-op. Solid presentation. Sometimes fighting four on 100 feels contrived. Ability to save anywhere can give missions a trial-and-error feel.
Verdict_Sum: Varied and interesting campaign. Tons of multiplayer modes, including co-op. Solid presentation. Sometimes fighting four on 100 feels contrived.

name: Tom Clancy's EndWar
IGN_title: Tom Clancy's EndWar Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: Tom Clancy's EndWar Review - GameSpot
IGN_text:
The accessibility and relative depth of EndWar is good news for those out there that have looked at the real-time strategy genre with a skeptical or confused eye in the past. If you haven't played an RTS before, this is a good place to start. Those who are old-hats might find some things lacking such as the uninspired single-player campaign and the fact that there isn't much noticeable variety between the three factions. The lack of pizzazz, unfortunately, won't do anything for either camp.

Still, EndWar offers something new, refreshing, and a little exciting for console players. It's sort of a coming of age when what could be seen as the last stalwart of the PC -- the RTS -- is made from the ground up with every classic convention put on the chopping block to please the couch player. This is a design that will surely be mimicked and improved upon in the future. For now, we have a good start and a game that is worth playing.
Gamespot_text: Innovative voice command mechanic makes you feel powerful. Fantastic audio and visuals put you in the thick of the action. Persistent online campaign makes matches feel meaningful. Different match types make good use of uplink capture mechanic. Single-player campaign has no story to speak of. All three factions play the same way. Limited unit types make for simple rock-paper-scissors skirmishes.
Verdict_Sum: Fantastic audio and visuals put you in the thick of the action. Persistent online campaign makes matches feel meaningful. Different match types make good use of uplink capture mechanic. Single-player campaign has no story to speak of.

Still too arcadelike for old-school PC Rainbow fans. No mission planning. Artificial intelligence can be inconsistent at times.
Verdict_Sum: Detailed character and weapon models, intricate environments. Slower, more tactical pace to gameplay. Sharp, compelling sound effects. Great variety of weapons and attachments.

name: Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege
IGN_title: Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege - Review - IGN

name: Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Vegas
IGN_title: Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six: Vegas Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Vegas Review - GameSpot
IGN_text: Though a took a while for it to get to the PlayStation 3, Rainbow Six: Vegas is a great shooter and should be picked up by anyone who's even remotely into tactical shooters. The series' strength has always been its online play, but Vegas manages to bring an engaging single-player experience to the table as well. With a total of 20 multiplayer maps, the ability to play through the whole game cooperatively online, terrorist hunt and the single-player missions, there's a whole lot to this package and it shouldn't be passed up.
Gamespot_text: Intense tactical action that requires you to use cover realistically. Fast rope off of helicopters, rappel down buildings, and smash through windows like a real commando. Beautiful visuals that let you battle in a glittering first-world setting. Impressive multiplayer suite supports a wide range of cooperative and competitive games. Story features some standard plot devices and lacks a satisfying ending.
Verdict_Sum: Rainbow Six: Vegas is a great shooter and should be picked up by anyone who's even remotely into tactical shooters. The series' strength has always been its online play, but Vegas manages to bring an engaging single-player experience to the table as well. There's a whole lot to this package and it shouldn't be passed up.

name: Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Vegas 2
IGN_title: Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Vegas 2 Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Vegas 2 Review - GameSpot
IGN_text: As I said previously, the biggest problem that most will have with Vegas 2 is that it doesn’t differentiate itself enough from the first. It doesn’t feel like an expansion pack exactly–-it’s more than that--but it doesn’t feel like a full-fledged sequel either. For those who haven’t taken a stroll down the streets of Sin City than you needn’t look any further than Rainbow Six Vegas 2, but those looking for a sequel that surpasses the original in everyway imaginable will be disappointed.
Gamespot_text: Some of the best tactical shooter action on consoles to date. New sprint ability speeds up the whole game. The control scheme has evolved and is better than ever. Looks and sounds great. Takes too few risks. Your AI partners still go nuts occasionally.
Verdict_Sum: The biggest problem that most will have with Vegas 2 is that it doesn't differentiate itself enough from the first. New sprint ability speeds up the whole game. The control scheme has evolved and is better than ever.

Gamespot_text: Tense and exciting cooperative missions. Excellent competitive play gets the adrenaline flowing. The best missions invite you to experiment with guns and gadgets. Great high-stakes atmosphere pulls you into the core conflict. Various campaign idiosyncrasies disrupt the flow. Sam has lost some of his edge.
Verdict_Sum: Tense and exciting cooperative missions. Excellent competitive play gets the adrenaline flowing. Great high-stakes atmosphere pulls you into the core conflict.

name: Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell Chaos Theory
Gamespot_title: Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell Chaos Theory Review - GameSpot
Gamespot_text: Gorgeous visuals, especially the lighting effects and the environments. Improved, more open-ended single-player campaign. Innovative multiplayer mode is interesting, though difficult to master. New cooperative mode offers some unique thrills. Campaign gameplay is retouched but pretty similar to the previous games. Multiplayer caters to the hardcore--it's complicated and punishing to new players. Feels like it was built by committee--there's a notable lack of cohesion.
Verdict_Sum: Gorgeous visuals, especially the lighting effects and the environments. Improved, more open-ended single-player campaign. Innovative multiplayer mode is interesting, though difficult to master.

name: Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell Classic Trilogy HD
Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell Conviction
Gamespot_title: Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Conviction Review - GameSpot
Gamespot_text: Executions are a total rush. Superb storytelling gets you into Sam's head. Great soundtrack keeps you immersed. Cooperative play is a blast. Brief campaign doesn't offer much challenge. Interrogations are a missed opportunity. Stealth options are stripped down compared to previous games.
Verdict_Sum: Superb storytelling gets you into Sam's head. Great soundtrack keeps you immersed. Cooperative play is a blast. Brief campaign doesn't offer much challenge.

name: Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell Double Agent
IGN_title: Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell Double Agent Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell Double Agent Review - GameSpot
IGN_text: Unfortunately for gamers and fans of the Splinter Cell series, it appears that Ubisoft took the quick, easy route to gouging consumers, as opposed to the concealed, evil one.  The developers may not be deceptive about what the game offers, but it definitely doesn’t exemplify what the Wii is capable of, both graphically and control-wise.  A blatant rush-job, Splinter Cell Double Agent may appeal to hardcore fans of the series, but doesn’t offer anything new to the genre.
Gamespot_text: Challenging campaign features a better story than previous Splinter Cell games. Good amount of cooperative two-player missions. Solid competitive multiplayer mode. High replay value overall. Little in the way of new gameplay in the campaign. Fans may miss the old spies-versus-mercenaries multiplayer, which is gone here.
Verdict_Sum: Splinter Cell Double Agent may appeal to hardcore fans of the series, but doesn’t offer anything new to the genre. Fans may miss the old spies-versus-mercenaries multiplayer, which is gone here.

name: Tom Clancy's The Division
IGN_title: Tom Clancy's The Division Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: Tom Clancy's The Division Review - GameSpot
Game_Rant_title: Tom Clancy's The Division Review - Game Rant
PC_Gamer_title: Tom Clancy's The Division review - PC Gamer
IGN_text: There’s definitely some decent meat to chew on in The Division, but it’s usually surrounded by too much gristle to enjoy it for long. Both in combat and out, there are some clearly good ideas, especially the tense and dangerous Dark Zone. But they’re not spread evenly or interwoven cleanly enough to form a cohesive, consistently enjoyable loop. Ultimately, The Division’s overly busy, conflicted design philosophies drown its best ingredients in a bland slurry that never quite comes together into a cohesive dish.
Gamespot_text: Dense, detailed world. Intense campaign missions. Intricate, rewarding loot system. Impressive multiplayer integration. Clear structure with thoughtful touches throughout. Predictable enemy AI. Repetitive side missions. Mechanical annoyances like no crouch option.
PC_Gamer_text: The Division is a challenging co-op cover shooter and a gorgeous open world diminished by bloated and unnecessary RPG tropes.
Verdict_Sum: Both in combat and out, there are some clearly good ideas. But they’re not spread evenly or interwoven cleanly enough to form a cohesive, consistently enjoyable loop. Ultimately, The Division’s overly busy, conflicted design philosophies drown its best ingredients in a bland slurry.

name: Tomb Raider (VI) The Angel of Darkness
Tomb Raider Anniversary
IGN_title: Tomb Raider: Anniversary Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: Tomb Raider: Anniversary Review - GameSpot
IGN_text:
Tomb Raider: Anniversary for Wii is a competently executed enhanced 
port of the previously released PlayStation 2 affair that also happens to 
be good fun at its best and frustrating at its worst. Croft controls and 
looks better than she ever has before and yet she still has a long way to 
go if she's to provide real competition to the Prince of Persia, who has, 
in my mind, out-Tomb Raidered Tomb Raider in recent years. The Wii 
control additions really do add to the experience and the game looks 
pretty good, too. The end product is not exemplary, but it is a step in 
the right direction and it's also entertaining, particularly when you're 
jumping from ledge to ledge or swinging across chasms to the beat of 
moody music.  

Although I think it's just as good as previous versions of Anniversary, 
I've lowered the score of the game on Wii because little effort has been 
made to capitalize on the added horsepower of Nintendo's console. 
That the framerate regularly suffers in wide-open levels is really 
disappointing. I wouldn't call it a deal breaker, but an unfortunate 
oversight.
Gamespot_text: Strikes a balance between homage and new, exciting content. Acrobatic action adventure gameplay is challenging without being frustrating. Lara looks great and moves effortlessly. Adrenaline dodge makes combat more exciting. Doesn't take many chances with the Tomb Raider formula. Minor frame rate issues.
Verdict_Sum: Strikes a balance between homage and new, exciting content. Acrobatic action adventure gameplay is challenging without being frustrating. Lara looks great and moves effortlessly. Adrenaline dodge makes combat more exciting. Minor frame rate issues.

name: Tomb Raider Legend
IGN_title: Tomb Raider: Legend Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: Tomb Raider: Legend Review - GameSpot
IGN_text: When your unlockable mini-games are more fun than your main adventure, you're in trouble. Tomb Raider: Legend has too many frustrations to forgive, taking what could have been a good Persia-style platformer clone and knocking it down to bland mediocrity. If you're a Lara fan, stick with the one of the console versions of this Legend – there's much more fun to be had there.
Gamespot_text: Lara has tons of great-looking moves and abilities. Varied levels take you to exotic locations all over the world. Excellent voice work and sound. Great graphics and detailed environments. The game is short and not very challenging. Unstable frame rate. The camera is occasionally frustrating. Weak gunplay.
Verdict_Sum: Lara has tons of great-looking moves and abilities. Varied levels take you to exotic locations all over the world. Excellent voice work and sound. Great graphics and detailed environments. The game is short and not very challenging.

name: Tomb Raider Underworld
IGN_title: Tomb Raider: Underworld Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: Tomb Raider Underworld Review - GameSpot
IGN_text: Tomb Raider Underworld is a good game that Lara Croft fans will enjoy, but its not quite the experience that will live up to or even surpass that of Legend. Its a shame, really, because there was a large amount of promise, particularly with the What Could Lara Do? system, which highlighted good controls for the game, more realistic animations and exploration for Lara, and slightly improved combat. Unfortunately, the game was held back by What The Technology Couldnt, leaving Underworld firmly in Tomb Raider: Legends shadow. While the PC version has much sharper visuals and some tighter control, the camera can still hamper gameplay.
Gamespot_text: Excellent mix of outdoor, underground, and underwater locations. Lara's new moves add to her existing abilities. Some excellent level and puzzle design. Existing clipping and camera issues remain. Forgettable story and cliched dialogue. Lack of refinement to the core gameplay.
Verdict_Sum: Tomb Raider Underworld is a good game that Lara Croft fans will enjoy, but its not quite the experience that will live up to or even surpass that of Legend. While the PC version has much sharper visuals and some tighter control, the camera can still hamper gameplay.

name: Tomb Raider
Gamespot_title: Tomb Raider Review - GameSpot
Game_Rant_title: 'Tomb Raider' Review - Game Rant
PC_Gamer_title: Tomb Raider review - PC Gamer
Gamespot_text: Story believably builds Lara up from unsure academic to confident adventurer. Fascinating setting with a rich sense of history. Intense combat that offers a good deal of flexibility. Controls make physically overcoming the island's terrain a pleasure. Good assortment of tombs to raid, relics to collect, and puzzles to solve. Forgettable multiplayer component. Outside of Lara's character arc, story is predictable.
PC_Gamer_text: Visually stunning and meticulously staged, but hindered by limited depth and stifling linearity.
Verdict_Sum: Fascinating setting with a rich sense of history. Intense combat that offers a good deal of flexibility. Good assortment of tombs to raid, relics to collect, and puzzles to solve. Forgettable multiplayer component.

Gamespot_title: Tony Hawk's American Sk8land Review - GameSpot

Verdict_Sum: Great graphics. Ability to add your own custom sound effects. Plays a lot like the console games. Online scoreboards. No graffiti mode.

name: Tony Hawk's American Wasteland (Old all region sales)
Tony Hawk's American Wasteland (Weekly american sales)
Tony Hawk's American Wasteland
Gamespot_title: Tony Hawk's American Wasteland Review - GameSpot
Gamespot_text: Compelling story mode. Interesting bmx trick system. Game contains a healthy dose of crunk juice. 360 controller's four shoulder buttons are perfect for playing this style of game. Character models and textures look pretty bad in HD resolutions. Classic mode contains old levels that aren't exactly classic. Graphical glitches further mar the game's visuals. Story mode holds your hand every step of the way. Costs $10 more than other versions for no good reason.
Verdict_Sum: Compelling story mode. Interesting bmx trick system. 360 controller's four shoulder buttons are perfect for playing this style of game. Graphical glitches further mar the game's visuals.

name: Tony Hawk's Downhill Jam
IGN_title: Tony Hawk's Downhill Jam Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: Tony Hawk's Downhill Jam Review - GameSpot
IGN_text: While the Tony Hawk series has certainly started to age and it's nice to see Activision attempt to mix things up, Downhill Jam simply does not work on a number of levels. It's entirely too easy, there are presentation problems, its racing and trick mix doesn't let either stand out and so on. It does offer up a number of different event types while mixing up the locations and throwing new unlockables at you, so even though it's not all that fun you might find yourself sticking around for one more race. Regardless though, this simply isn't the right direction for the series and only casual gamers will find much to like here.
Gamespot_text: Moves fast. Steering with the Wii Remote works pretty well. Oversimplified trick system gets in the way. Not enough track variety. Kind of ugly, once you get past the high speed.
Verdict_Sum: Moves fast. Steering with the Wii Remote works pretty well. Oversimplified trick system gets in the way. Not enough track variety. Kind of ugly, once you get past the high speed.

name: Tony Hawk's Motion
IGN_title: Tony Hawk's Motion Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: Tony Hawk's Motion - Review - GameFAQs
IGN_text:
Our industry is oversaturated with a plethora of “just ship it” games, and while Tony Hawk’s Motion isn’t the worst offender out there, it is the most recent one.  Activision is out to capture the casual Wii market on DS, adding in a motion pack along with two very sub-par games in an attempt to use Tony Hawk’s brand, and the “two for one” double pack strategy to push units this holiday season.  It fails as a game, but only time will tell if it fails as a marketing plan, since – let’s face it – not everyone out there buying games knows a lemon when they see one.

Activision’s motion pack works.  The Tony Hawk brand works.  Aiming DS products to casual users works.  But it doesn’t work like this, and what could have been a great title to push new tech (an ambitious move has been made by Activision to try and expand Nintendo’s own expanded marketplace) with a fully-funded, legit contender against other DS titles is instead more or less a shovelware design with an interesting piece of tech included.  A full-fledged, AAA effort with the motion pack at its side could be a great piece of product.  Tony Hawk’s Motion, on the other hand, is a lacking package that players would do well to ignore; especially since the DSi (and lack of GBA port for the new motion pack) is on its way in a matter of months.
Verdict_Sum: Activision is out to capture the casual Wii market on DS, adding in a motion pack along with two very sub-par games in an attempt to use Tony Hawk’s brand. A full-fledged, AAA effort with the motion pack at its side could be a great piece of product. Tony Hawk's Motion, on the other hand, is a lacking package that players would

Game_Rant_title: 'Tony Hawk's Pro Skater HD' Review - Game Rant
IGN_text: Tony Hawk's Pro Skater HD is proof positive that sometimes all you really need to kickstart a series is to go back to its roots. While there are still a few glitches and notable absences we'd like to see ironed out, we're already dreaming up which levels, moves, and modes we'll see in future DLC packs. Tony Hawk definitely rewards your $15 with equal parts fun and nostalgia.
Gamespot_text: Plays like classic Tony Hawk. Nicely detailed HD visuals. Plenty of unlockables. Meager and questionable choice of levels. Awkward bail animations and numerous visual quirks. Missing several game modes from THPS2.
Verdict_Sum: Plays like classic Tony Hawk. Nicely detailed HD visuals. Plenty of unlockables. Meager and questionable choice of levels. Awkward bail animations and numerous visual quirks. Missing several game modes from THPS2.

name: Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 3
IGN_title: Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 3 Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 3 Review - GameSpot
IGN_text: Though THPS3 came out on PS2 several month ago, it doesn't come off as stale or overdone.  Certainly anyone who has never played the game should pick it up.  It's something all gamers should experience.  The graphics are solid, the soundtrack is great, and it's incredibly fun.  If you've already got the game on another console, there are some extras for the Xbox that may merit a trade-in.  The custom soundtrack ability alone is worth it to me.  Plus it's got a cool new character and a new level that Activision calls a preview of things to come in Hawk 4.  Tony Hawk came around several years ago and knocked the industry silly.  It's responsible for spawning numerous imitators, but the original is still far and away the king, baby.
Gamespot_text: N/A. .
Verdict_Sum: The graphics are solid, the soundtrack is great, and it's incredibly fun. It's got a cool new character and a new level that Activision calls a preview of things to come in Hawk 4.

name: Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 4
IGN_title: Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 4 Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 4 Review - GameSpot
IGN_text:
Tony Hawk 4 is by far the best skateboarding title around and head and shoulders above its "me-too" competition. I just don't think there's enough newness here for a casual Xbox gamer to drop another $50 so soon after buying Tony Hawk 3 and we're still not playing the Hawkman online yet. If ever there was a game that could benefit from steady doses of downloadable content through a service like Xbox Live it's Tony Hawk's Pro Skater. What serious Hawk fan wouldn't be willing to buy a game once and keep upgrading it with new levels, for a small fee even, for months to come? In the end, the Tony Hawk series' biggest drawback is that number 4 is facing strong competition from number 3 on the Xbox. 

Hawk 4 is the best the series has to offer, but if you picked up Hawk 3 anytime in the last six months, then I wouldn't be in any hurry to rush out and pay full price for this game at this time. For all but the most ardent Tony Hawk fans, it makes more sense to wait awhile and see what other upcoming games may tickle your fancy because there are plenty of other holiday titles vying for your dollar that would do more for your library.
Gamespot_text: N/A. .
Verdict_Sum: Tony Hawk 4 is by far the best skateboarding title around and head and shoulders above its "me-too" competition. I just don't think there's enough newness here for a casual Xbox gamer to drop another $50. There are plenty of other holiday titles vying for your dollar that would do more for your library.

name: Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 5
IGN_title: Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 5 Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 5 Review - GameSpot
Game_Rant_title: Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 5 Review - Game Rant
IGN_text: Tony Hawk’s Pro Skater 5’s rare moments of nostalgic joy are drowned out by its abundance of poorly thought out levels, control problems, bugs, and its glaring lack of attitude. It boggles the mind that a $60 game in 2015 can be riddled with so many technical issues.
Gamespot_text: Skating is occasionally fun. Slam mechanic disturbs the series' tried-and-true gameplay. Online connectivity hampers the single player experience. Graphical and technical glitches are a constant annoyance. Uninspired maps and simple challenges fail to hold your interest. Poor and insufficient UI.
Verdict_Sum: Skating is occasionally fun. Online connectivity hampers the single player experience. Graphical and technical glitches are a constant annoyance. Uninspired maps and simple challenges fail to hold your interest. Poor and insufficient UI.

name: Tony Hawk's Project 8
IGN_title: Tony Hawk's Project 8 Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: Tony Hawk's Project 8 Review - GameSpot
IGN_text:
It isn’t easy being the first person to ever give a Tony Hawk console game under an 8, but it has to be done. While the Nail the Trick feature is brilliant, it’s just one small addition to what is largely the same game. Yes, it is now one seamless world, but that doesn’t necessarily make for a better experience. In fact, the level design may have suffered because of it. 

This doesn’t mean that the Tony Hawk franchise is at an end. Far from it. The addictiveness is still there. Despite its flaws and some of its recurring bugs, it’s hard not to enjoy playing Tony Hawk’s Project 8.

There is almost unlimited potential for Tony Hawk with next-gen software, but Neversoft needs to think a bit more out of the box. I’m not talking about bringing us back to the dark days of THUG, but why not take a cue from Amped 2 and meld the single-player world with online play? Or give us back the joy of playing the main mode as a variety of skating pros and building them into giants of the industry? Or why not take us through Tony Hawk’s career from young pioneer to king of the sport? Heck, I’d be happy to see Tony Hawk 2 re-imagined for the new generation. I hope Neversoft is up to the challenge of making the Tony Hawk series brilliant again, because I still love the series. I just want my love to be justified.
Gamespot_text: Decent career mode with plenty of goals. Controls often feel imprecise. Long loading times. No online mode. New combo meter timer takes some of the skill out of the game.
Verdict_Sum: The Nail the Trick feature is brilliant, but it's just one small addition to what is largely the same game. Yes, it is now one seamless world, but that doesn't necessarily make for a better experience. Long loading times. No online mode. New combo meter timer takes some of the skill out of the game.

name: Tony Hawk's Proving Ground
IGN_title: Tony Hawk's Proving Ground Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: Tony Hawk's Proving Ground Review - GameSpot
IGN_text: Tony Hawk's Proving Ground is a relatively solid game, but it really doesn't do anything new and significant. We've seen all of the good parts from the game multiple, multiple times now, and it really just feels like we're playing a large expansion pack. That doesn't mean that it's not fun, but it does mean that it's rather old hat.
Gamespot_text: Lots of goals of varying skill levels will keep completists very busy. New moves like the aggro kick and nail the grab bring something new to the game. New nail the manual move feels half-baked. Rigger goals depend too heavily on a poor level editor. Little graphical glitches bring the look of the game down a bit. Seems to suffer from a handful of technical issues that make some goals harder than they should be.
Verdict_Sum: Tony Hawk's Proving Ground is a relatively solid game, but it really doesn't do anything new and significant. Lots of goals of varying skill levels will keep completists very busy. New moves like the aggro kick and nail the grab bring something new to the game.

name: Tony Hawk's Underground 2 Remix
Gamespot_title: Tony Hawk's Underground 2 Remix Review - GameSpot
Gamespot_text: Looks almost exactly like the PlayStation 2 version.. Controls well.. The four new levels for this version are great.. Anyone that played THUG2 on consoles won't find much new here.. Occasional visual glitches on your created skater.. Would have really benefited from online multiplayer..
Verdict_Sum: The four new levels for this version are great. Anyone that played THUG2 on consoles won't find much new here. Occasional visual glitches on your created skater.

name: Tony Hawk's Underground
Gamespot_title: Tony Hawk's Underground Review - GameSpot
Gamespot_text: N/A. .

name: Tony Hawk's Underground 2
Gamespot_title: Tony Hawk's Underground 2 Review - GameSpot
Gamespot_text: N/A. .

name: War of the Monsters
Gamespot_title: War of the Monsters Review - GameSpot
Gamespot_text: N/A. .

name: War of the Roses Balance Beta
War of the Roses Kingmaker
Gamespot_title: War of the Roses: Kingmaker - Review - GameFAQs

name: War of the Roses
IGN_title: War of the Roses Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: War of the Roses Review - GameSpot
PC_Gamer_title: War of the Roses review - PC Gamer
IGN_text: War of the Roses isn’t quite Mount and Blade or Battlefield, but it manages to walk a fine line between the two models to produce an innovative and enjoyable experience. Its mere two gameplay modes and seven maps feel limited and its learning curve might frighten away the most casual players, but its combat feels properly bloody and rewarding, and there’s enough customization available here to stave off any fears of a winter of discontent. There’s a chance that Fatshark will make the price of admission easier to swallow with its promises of regular upcoming content, but, even in its current state, it's one of the best (and only) takes on chaotic open medieval combat.
Gamespot_text: Combat is chaotic and fun. Tons of weapon customization options. Beautiful map designs. With only two modes, battles can grow repetitive.
PC_Gamer_text: A slight but fun third-person medieval melee game. Its definitely different, but needs more bulking out.
Verdict_Sum: War of the Roses isn't quite Mount and Blade or Battlefield, but it manages to walk a fine line between the two models. Its mere two gameplay modes and seven maps feel limited and its learning curve might frighten away the most casual players, but its combat feels properly bloody and rewarding.

name: War of the Vikings
IGN_title: War of the Vikings Review - IGN
PC_Gamer_title: War of the Vikings review - PC Gamer
IGN_text: You know how in war movies, when the hero and villain finally see each other on the battlefield, everyone else stands aside and lets them fight? War of the Vikings shows what happens when that courtesy is not honored. The mechanics don’t match the execution, and everything suffers as a result.
PC_Gamer_text: Streamlined in every way, War of the Vikings cut too much meat from the bone and left nothing to chew on.
Verdict_Sum: Streamlined in every way, War of the Vikings cut too much meat from the bone. The mechanics don't match the execution, and everything suffers as a result.

name: Warhammer 40,000 Armageddon
Gamespot_title: Warhammer 40,000: Armageddon - Review - GameFAQs

name: Warhammer 40,000 Dawn of War  Dark Crusade
Warhammer 40,000 Dawn of War  Winter Assault
Warhammer 40,000 Dawn of War - Game of the Year Edition
Warhammer 40,000 Dawn of War II  Retribution
Warhammer 40,000 Dawn of War II - Chaos Rising
Gamespot_title: Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II - Chaos Rising Review
Gamespot_text: Every bit as entertaining as Dawn of War II. Corruption mechanic lets you betray the false emperor. Chaos faction brings new "blood for the blood god". Abundant options for cooperative and competitive play. Cool new heroes reinvigorate Last Stand. Corruption doesn't alter the story until the ending cutscene. Last Stand still limited to one map. Games for Windows Live still clumsy and inconvenient.
Verdict_Sum: Every bit as entertaining as Dawn of War II. Corruption mechanic lets you betray the false emperor. Chaos faction brings new "blood for the blood god. Abundant options for cooperative and competitive play.

name: Warhammer 40,000 Dawn of War II
IGN_title: Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II Review - GameSpot
IGN_text: Relic has made a lot of bold decisions with Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II, some of which are sure to turn off parts of the RTS hardcore base, the most obvious being the elimination of base building. Yet as players we can't continue to accept the same kinds of games, complain about stagnation, and then turn our backs when somebody does something different. In the campaign portion of the game Relic blended elements of action-RPGs and real-time strategy games and succeeded in producing a new and entertaining kind of experience. The missions could be more interesting and quality of narrative delivery stronger, but what's here is a terrific alternative to the standard base-bashing real-time strategy campaigns, hopefully something Relic is able to expand and further improve with expansions. A full multiplayer suite and four playable races are there waiting for you when you're through with the campaign, and should provide lots of fast-paced bouts of brutal conflict online and in skirmishes against the AI. While the overall formula could still use some fine-tuning, the current product is one part hypercharged tactical combat, one part streamlined competitive RTS, and entirely worth playing.
Gamespot_text: Fun, exciting online play will keep you under its spell. Fantastic production values. The loot collecting is fun and addictive. Co-op play lets a buddy join your campaign in progress. Campaign doesn't feature much strategy. Few multiplayer maps. Only 1 vs. 1 and 3 vs. 3 matches.
Verdict_Sum: Fun, exciting online play will keep you under its spell. Fantastic production values. Co-op play lets a buddy join your campaign in progress. Campaign doesn't feature much strategy. Few multiplayer maps.

name: Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War
IGN_title: Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War Review - GameSpot
Game_Rant_title: Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War 3 Review - Game Rant
IGN_text:
Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War is the first game in a long, long time that has even come close to doing the franchise justice. The fact that it hits the nail on the head isn't necessarily surprising; it's just been such a long wait that it's almost emotional. Everything from the drab and blasted landscapes to the perfectly realized models and varied animations make a perfect host for this ultra-violent future to inhabit.

Nothing about the gameplay will really surprise anyone (though the addition of reinforceable squads is pretty neat) but it doesn't particularly matter. The factions are balanced very well, the battles are entertaining enough to make excitable gamers pee their pants, and the pace keeps players attention stuck to the screen at all times. Relic kicked ass creating a great piece of entertainment.
Gamespot_text: N/A. .
Verdict_Sum: Nothing about the gameplay will really surprise anyone (though the addition of reinforceable squads is pretty neat) The factions are balanced very well, the battles are entertaining enough to make excitable gamers pee their pants.

name: Warhammer 40,000 Kill Team
Gamespot_title: Warhammer 40,000: Kill Team Review - GameSpot
Gamespot_text: Slaughtering Orks is mindless fun. Ork kroozer environment is grim and compelling. Shallow gameplay doesn't hold up for long. Co-op is local only. Cheap deaths and poor checkpoint placement can be frustrating.
Verdict_Sum: Slaughtering Orks is mindless fun. Ork kroozer environment is grim and compelling. Shallow gameplay doesn't hold up for long. Co-op is local only.

name: Warhammer 40,000 Regicide
PC_Gamer_title: Warhammer 40,000: Regicide review - PC Gamer
PC_Gamer_text: A cute chess set for 40K fans and an unusual twist on the classic game, but skip the campaign.
Verdict_Sum: A cute chess set for 40K fans and an unusual twist on the classic game, but skip the campaign.

name: Warhammer 40,000 Space Marine
IGN_title: Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine Review - GameSpot
Game_Rant_title: 'Warhammer 40000: Space Marine' Review - Game Rant
PC_Gamer_title: Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 review - PC Gamer
IGN_text: Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 is a terrific third-person shooter with a compelling story, loads of weapons that are a blast to use, and a healthy variety of enemies to use them on. It once again borrows many of its ideas from the Gears of War series, but they’re good ideas, and Space Marine 2 does a fine job of making them its own. And while the Operations PvE mode that accompanies it doesn’t currently offer enough to keep me coming back, the deep customization options for your Space Marine do look promising if it’s supported in post-launch updates as planned. Besides, when you’re eviscerating aliens on planets as pretty as these, it’s hard not to leave satisfied.
Gamespot_text: Captures the brutality of the Warhammer 40K universe. Entertaining mix of shooting and melee action. It's fun to don a jump pack and stomp on Orks. The mindless slaughter lacks variety. Dull story, dull characters. Lame final boss.
PC_Gamer_text: Fans of Warhammer 40,000 will be delighted by the spectacle and authenticity—but ultimately disappointed by messy action and unengaging multiplayer.
Verdict_Sum: Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 is a terrific third-person shooter with a compelling story, loads of weapons that are a blast to use, and a healthy variety of enemies to use them on. It once again borrows many of its ideas from the Gears of War series, but they’re good ideas. The Operations PvE mode that accompanies it doesn’

name: Warhammer 40,000 Storm of Vengeance Bad Moon Clan
Warhammer 40,000 Storm of Vengeance Death Skulls Clan
Warhammer 40,000 Storm of Vengeance Deathwing Terminator
Warhammer 40,000 Storm of Vengeance Imperial Guard Faction
Warhammer 40,000: Fire Warrior
Gamespot_title: Warhammer 40,000: Fire Warrior Review - GameSpot
Gamespot_text: N/A. .

name: Warhammer 40,000: Squad Command
IGN_title: Warhammer 40,000: Squad Command Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: Warhammer 40,000: Squad Command Review - GameSpot
IGN_text:
Warhammer 40,000: Squad Command has a few strong features and can, occasionally, be fun, but we're extremely hesitant to recommend it because there are so many mechanical issues at hand. Granted, we eventually adapted to the problems and enjoyed ourselves in the later missions (once we got used to the wonky controls), but we shouldn't have to adapt to poor mechanics in order to enjoy the title.

Warhammer fans: the ability to control classic Warhammer units may make this game more appealing to you, but anyone interested in the title should be extremely cautious before investing the time and money. The positive elements just barely outweigh the bad.
Gamespot_text: Solid use of Warhammer license and distinctive miniature designs. Straightforward, easy-to-understand turn-based interface. Excellent level design with loads of destructible terrain. Limited and annoying camera angles. Odd design choices make it difficult to control troops.
Verdict_Sum: Solid use of Warhammer license and distinctive miniature designs. Straightforward, easy-to-understand turn-based interface. Excellent level design with loads of destructible terrain. Limited and annoying camera angles.

name: World of Goo
IGN_title: World of Goo Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: World of Goo Review - GameSpot
IGN_text:
World of Goo is an amazing downloadable PC game that you simply must buy. It's got beautiful music. And it controls really well. So if you value any or all of these qualities, and hopefully you do, you should not hesitate to add it to your My Games List via Steam. I've given it a slightly lower score on PC versus WiiWare because it lacks the cooperative mode found in the Nintendo build and also because it 
retails for $5 more. But even at $20, you'll be hard-pressed to find a 
better, more engrossing downloadable game.
Gamespot_text: Brilliant design loaded with gameplay depth. Varied levels sporting wide-ranging objectives and different types of goo. Quirky, surreal sense of humor. Fantastic, atmospheric soundtrack. The controls can't always keep up with the action. Visuals aren't as vibrant as they could be given the cartoony premise.
Verdict_Sum: World of Goo is an amazing downloadable PC game that you simply must buy. It's got beautiful music and it controls really well. I've given it a slightly lower score on PC versus WiiWare.

name: World of Outlaws: Sprint Cars
IGN_title: World of Outlaws: Sprint Cars Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: World of Outlaws: Sprint Cars Review - GameSpot
IGN_text:
I understand wanting to support your favorite niche sport. Back in the day, I bought two crappy ECW games from Acclaim’s pro wrestling line because I wanted to support my favorite federation. Those games weren’t good and neither is World of Outlaws: Championship Sprint. Even if you’re a diehard fan of the motorsport, you’re not getting a worthwhile experience here – your favorite drivers are reduced to names on the ticker and tiny headshots on statistic screens. 

The racing isn’t engaging, exciting, or energetic, and that (along with a bunch of other oversights) sinks this game.
Gamespot_text: Lengthy and rewarding Career mode. Believable AI opponents. Ugly and technically challenged visuals. Controls take a good while to feel comfortable. Limited and mostly disappointing multiplayer options.
Verdict_Sum: The racing isn't engaging, exciting, or energetic, and that (along with a bunch of other oversights) sinks this game. Ugly and technically challenged visuals take a good while to feel comfortable. Limited and mostly disappointing multiplayer options.

name: World of Warcraft: Cataclysm
IGN_title: World of Warcraft: Cataclysm Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: World of Warcraft: Cataclysm Review - GameSpot
PC_Gamer_title: World of Warcraft: Cataclysm Review - PC Gamer
IGN_text: If you include the vast changes to the core game, Cataclysm is far and away the most impressive expansion to an MMO ever made, but if you just isolate what Cataclysm itself gets you, it's ultimately less content than Wrath of the Lich King. It's also better content than Wrath, with engaging storylines, inventive quests, and some very striking visuals. Even without the core Azeroth changes, Cataclysm is an excellent expansion in its own right, and worthy of your attention whether you're a veteran of Northrend or a grunt just getting your toes wet for the first time.
Gamespot_text: New zones with satisfying stories and varied quests are the best to date. Fun and very different starter zones for new races. Guild leveling and rewards systems are great additions. Level and gear restrictions introduced for battlegrounds and dungeons respectively. Masterful use of phasing technology makes your actions feel impactful. New archaeology profession isn't fun. Not enough zones to level a second character without repeating lots of content.
PC_Gamer_text: A triumph. Competitors beware: this is the best MMO in the world. Once you're hooked it's impossible to stop playing.
Verdict_Sum: New zones with satisfying stories and varied quests. Guild leveling and rewards systems are great additions. Level and gear restrictions introduced for battlegrounds and dungeons respectively. New archaeology profession isn't fun. Not enough zones to level a second character without repeating lots of content.

name: World of Warcraft: Legion
IGN_title: World of Warcraft: Legion Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: World of Warcraft: Legion Review - GameSpot
Game_Rant_title: World of Warcraft: Legion Review - Game Rant
PC_Gamer_title: World of Warcraft: Legion review - PC Gamer
IGN_text: After months of missteps, Legion shows World of Warcraft finding its footing again and asserting its relevance after more than a decade. Many elements make this an expansion worth enjoying, including class halls, gigantic zones filled with memorable stories, better socialization, the actiony new Demon Hunter class, and world quests. The one big question mark is whether Blizzard can maintain that energy after launch, but so far the outlook seems promising.
Gamespot_text: A story with genuine stakes and consequences. Breathtaking sights in game's gorgeous new zones. PvE dungeons emphasize teamwork and coordination right out of the gate. Demon Hunter class adds a new versatility to exploration. Reaching the level cap happens in a flash. Reliance on two decades of lore may alienate new players..
PC_Gamer_text: If Blizzard can continue to deliver, Legion sets the stage for what could be the best chapter of World of Warcraft yet.
Verdict_Sum: After months of missteps, Legion shows World of Warcraft finding its footing again and asserting its relevance after more than a decade. Many elements make this an expansion worth enjoying, including class halls, gigantic zones filled with memorable stories, and the actiony new Demon Hunter class. The one big question mark is whether Blizzard can maintain that energy after launch, but so far the outlook seems promising.

name: World of Warcraft: Mists of Pandaria
IGN_title: World of Warcraft: Mists of Pandaria Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: World of Warcraft: Mists of Pandaria Review - GameSpot
PC_Gamer_title: World of Warcraft: Mists of Pandaria review | PC Gamer
IGN_text: Mists of Pandaria is an expansion built for the high level player that shows off Blizzard’s skill with dungeon design and offers plenty of rewards for long-term play. It’s also the best questing in World of Warcraft, with strong emphasis on storytelling, resulting in an entertaining run from 85 to 90 that seldom tumbles into tedium. While not all the new systems dazzle, more than anything, Mists proves that Blizzard’s venerable MMO is still one of the best around, a mix of breezy questing, top tier class design, and multiple systems to encourage the cutthroat competition that props up the end game.  World of Warcraft is still devilishly effective at teasing god-like power, where you start with nothing and climb step by step up a colossal mountain of progression until you can, someday, spike a flag into its peak, look out across the vastness of your experience and revel in a sublime sense of dominance.
Gamespot_text: Plenty of activities to keep you engaged. Pandaren race and monk class offer variety. Gorgeous expanses to explore. Challenge mode is a great way to test your skills. Phasing gets in the way of adding friends to the fold. Pet battle system lacks the thrill of discovery.
PC_Gamer_text: A reminder of what made Warcraft the king of its genre for eight years... but also that eight years is a long time.
Verdict_Sum: Mists of Pandaria is an expansion built for the high level player. Shows off Blizzard's skill with dungeon design and offers plenty of rewards for long-term play. It’s also the best questing in World of Warcraft, with strong emphasis on storytelling.

name: World of Warcraft: The Burning Crusade
IGN_title: World of Warcraft: The Burning Crusade Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: World of Warcraft: The Burning Crusade Review - GameSpot
IGN_text:
Few World of Warcraft players would consider their experience complete without the additions that The Burning Crusade brings. The ridiculous first-day sales numbers support this. If you didn't care for the gameplay of the original game, there's nothing here that's going to change your mind. Still, players who are new to MMOs won't find a better introduction than the two new races found here.

For players who already love the game and have been anxious to break through the level cap, The Burning Crusade is a done deal. They bought it on day one and are now happily butting up against the new level cap.

Still, the forty-dollar price tag is a bit steep, particularly for players who aren't inclined to try the new races or aren't powerful enough yet to venture into Outland. Considering the quality of the content in the original game, there's certainly no big rush for mid-level types to jump right into The Burning Crusade.
Gamespot_text: Beautiful new environments. Fun and varied world-PVP objectives. Lots of great new dungeons. Great orchestral soundtrack. Some quests are very repetitive. A lot of preexisting content is now obsolete.
Verdict_Sum: For players who already love the game, The Burning Crusade is a done deal. Still, the forty-dollar price tag is a bit steep, particularly for players who aren't inclined to try the new races or aren't powerful enough yet.

name: World of Warcraft: Wrath of the Lich King
IGN_title: World of Warcraft: Wrath of the Lich King Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: World of Warcraft: Wrath of the Lich King Review - GameSpot
IGN_text:
With Wrath of the Lich King, World of Warcraft's play style has been tweaked to be more accessible, addictive, and deeper. Any longtime player is sure to be pleased with what Blizzard's done here since it gives the higher level population a wealth of new content for play as well as improves the overall look of the world. And let's be honest, if you're going to spend hundreds of hours in a virtual space, it helps if it's pretty. It's an MMO system that works, as the game's success underlines, but you've got to ask yourself after four years how long this kind of momentumcan last. Perhaps within the next two years, or by the time the next World of Warcraft expansion is released, there'll be a clearer answer.

As for now, Blizzard is more than content to build on World of Warcraft's formula, improving and refining nearly every aspect of the game, delivering new quest systems, a better and more focused narrative, loads of new goals to chase by yourself or with friends, and made acclimating to its world's complexities a process generally free of the headaches of something like CCP's EVE Online. Those who've yet to jump in should absolutely do so; it's hard to imagine anyone being disappointed with such a well-run, polished product that offers so many reward strata and diverse styles of gameplay.
Gamespot_text: Hundreds of interesting and varied quests. Death knight class is a lot of fun to play. Great-looking environments. Dungeons are now accessible to all players. Your actions have an impact on the world around you. Some character and item models are recycled. No content for new players.
Verdict_Sum: With Wrath of the Lich King, World of Warcraft's play style has been tweaked to be more accessible, addictive, and deeper. Dungeons are now accessible to all players. Your actions have an impact on the world around you. Some character and item models are recycled.

name: World of Warcraft
IGN_title: World of Warcraft Review - IGN
Gamespot_title: World of Warcraft Review - GameSpot
IGN_text: World of Warcraft, like any MMO, is a tough game to score. Your play experience will have no concrete resolution, and content and character class balancing will make for a slightly different experience from one month to the next. And WoW III had some debilitating issues at launch trying to handle the record-breaking number of people filing in for subscriptions. After having written about the extremely long queues, they have dwindled to almost nothing, even at peak playing times, and the game has become much more stable. I still get the occasional crash, but WoW still has a polish that puts most other MMO launches to shame. Almost a victim of its own popularity, World of Warcraft quickly found its feet, serving up no fewer than eighty-eight servers across the country, with more likely on the way.
Gamespot_text: Huge, beautiful, seamless world. High streamlined and conducive to short or long play sessions. Exciting, action-packed combat. Elegant, easy-to-use interface. Excellent music and sound. Some stability issues immediately following launch. Player-versus-player elements not complete.
Verdict_Sum: WoW III had some debilitating issues at launch trying to handle the record-breaking number of people filing in for subscriptions. After having written about the extremely long queues, they have dwindled to almost nothing, even at peak playing times. I still get the occasional crash, but WoW still has a polish that puts most other MMO launches to shame.
